creditline: Lent by the Frederick R. Weisman Art Museum at the University of Minnesota, Minneapolis
department: Art of Africa and the Americas
description: large, carved, polychromed figure with painted beard and incised diamond design at center of long, protruding, stomach; carved bird at L and R sides of head; carved male figure at PL, and female at PR above head; carved bird at bottom between legs, and small carved faces at sides
text:
At the center of Abelam ritual life were very large spirit houses that were reserved for men. Most Abelam paintings and sculptures-characterized by strong colors and taut forms-were found in and around these buildings. One of their main functions was to teach initiates, through association and introspection, the history of the clan and the origin of the world.

This large figure of an ancestor spirit is hollow on the back and contains holes all around, indicating that it was once attached to a spirit house pole. Its base is eroded from long-term usage. The many animals and symbols allude to clan ancestors and mythical beings. Above the large head are two figures on either side, one of which represents a woman giving birth, a common theme in Abelam art.
title: Ancestor Figure
